messages.author: Wez
messages.text: nit: This should be re-named to make it clear it won't send to desktop processes, e.g. SendToNetwork or SendNetworkIPC

messages.author: Wez
messages.text: OK, it really feels like all this logic belongs in a DesktopSessionManager; that might be passed the DesktopSessionFactory to use to actually create desktops, for example.

messages.author: alexeypa (please no reviews)
messages.text:
On 2012/10/16 04:27:03, Wez wrote:
> nit: This should be re-named to make it clear it won't send to desktop
> processes, e.g. SendToNetwork or SendNetworkIPC

Done.

messages.author: alexeypa (please no reviews)
messages.text:
On 2012/10/16 04:27:03, Wez wrote:
> OK, it really feels like all this logic belongs in a DesktopSessionManager; that
> might be passed the DesktopSessionFactory to use to actually create desktops,
> for example.

DaemonProcess is that "DesktopSessionManager". Really, managing desktop sessions is 50% of what it is supposed to do. I don't think there is value in separating "DesktopSessionManager" out. It will add more boilerplate code without any benefit.

"DesktopSessionManager" makes sense on the other side - in the network/host process. There HospProcess is too large so it pays off to split it into smaller pieces.

messages.author: Wez
messages.text:
On 2012/10/16 16:48:09, alexeypa wrote:
> On 2012/10/16 04:27:03, Wez wrote:
> > OK, it really feels like all this logic belongs in a DesktopSessionManager;
> that
> > might be passed the DesktopSessionFactory to use to actually create desktops,
> > for example.
> 
> DaemonProcess is that "DesktopSessionManager". Really, managing desktop sessions
> is 50% of what it is supposed to do. I don't think there is value in separating
> "DesktopSessionManager" out. It will add more boilerplate code without any
> benefit.
> 
> "DesktopSessionManager" makes sense on the other side - in the network/host
> process. There HospProcess is too large so it pays off to split it into smaller
> pieces.

DaemonProcess also manages the network process, and may in future perform other functions; the desktop session management feels like a natural fit for hiving off into its own component for DaemonProcess to use.  Not an issue for this CL, though.

messages.author: alexeypa (please no reviews)
messages.text:
On 2012/10/16 21:53:20, Wez wrote:
> DaemonProcess also manages the network process, and may in
> future perform other functions; the desktop session
> management feels like a natural fit for hiving
> off into its own component for DaemonProcess to use.

This is exactly the reason why we have so much boilerplate code. Instead of a single class we end up with two (or even three) classes and an interface. They will have to know enough about each other to be able to pass messages between desktop and network channels. It is only worth it when the parts are complex enough, otherwise it will be tons of worthless code.

messages.author: Wez
messages.text: Suggest "Represents the desktop session for a connected terminal.  Each desktop session has a unique identifier used by cross-platform code to refer to it."

messages.author: Wez
messages.text: Does this need to be in the public interface?  Won't the caller own the DaemonProcess, in effect?

On 2012/10/16 04:27:03, Wez wrote:
> Suggest "Represents the desktop session for a connected terminal.  Each desktop
> session has a unique identifier used by cross-platform code to refer to it."

Done.

> Does this need to be in the public interface?

Made it protected.

> Won't the caller own the DaemonProcess, in effect?

No, it is called by DesktopSessionWin.

messages.author: alexeypa (please no reviews)
messages.text:
On 2012/10/16 04:27:03, Wez wrote:
> If you never expect this to happen in reality then consider LOG(FATAL) rather
> than re-starting the network process, so that we'll get corresponding crash
> reports.

We are crossing a privilege boundary here. The ID is generated by a less privileged process validated by a more privileged process. If we crash it would mean that the 1st process would be able to crash the 2nd one. I think restarting the process is a proper action. We could also ask the lest privileged process to crash instead. This will be a follow up CL then.

messages.author: alexeypa (please no reviews)

> nit: clean up?

Done.

messages.author: alexeypa (please no reviews)
messages.text:
On 2012/10/16 04:27:03, Wez wrote:
> What you mean is that CloseDesktopSession() may be
> triggered by either the daemon process in response 
> to the desktop session being closed, or by the
> network process in response to client disconnect,

Yes.

> so we'll often get it called
> twice during teardown of a desktop session?

No. I mean that those two events could happen simultaneously.

> nit: CloseAllDesktopSessions() implies it's equivalent to calling

messages.author: Wez
messages.text:
On 2012/10/16 16:48:09, alexeypa wrote:
> On 2012/10/16 04:27:03, Wez wrote:
> > If you never expect this to happen in reality then consider LOG(FATAL) rather
> > than re-starting the network process, so that we'll get corresponding crash
> > reports.
> 
> We are crossing a privilege boundary here. The ID is generated by a less
> privileged process validated by a more privileged process. If we crash it would
> mean that the 1st process would be able to crash the 2nd one. I think restarting
> the process is a proper action. We could also ask the lest privileged process to
> crash instead. This will be a follow up CL then.

The less-privileged process is instead triggering logging, which is clearly less-bad but still a potential issue unless we limit logging in some way. :-/  I don't think a controlled crash is a problem here, since although it's a less-privileged process, it's _our_ less-privileged process, so badly-formed data from it indicates it's compromised, in which case crashing our host is probably the least of the issues with the host system.  Let's discuss how to handle this for a follow-up CL though.

messages.author: Wez
messages.text:
On 2012/10/16 16:48:09, alexeypa wrote:
> On 2012/10/16 04:27:03, Wez wrote:
> > What you mean is that CloseDesktopSession() may be
> > triggered by either the daemon process in response 
> > to the desktop session being closed, or by the
> > network process in response to client disconnect,
> 
> Yes.
> 
> > so we'll often get it called
> > twice during teardown of a desktop session?
> 
> No. I mean that those two events could happen simultaneously.
> 

And the events get queued & processed by the same thread, so it ends up getting called twice, surely?

messages.author: alexeypa (please no reviews)
messages.text:
On 2012/10/16 21:53:20, Wez wrote:
> And the events get queued & processed by the same thread, so it ends up getting
> called twice, surely?

It can be called twice. It has very low chances of happening.

Consider defining these mocks in their own remoting/host/win/host_mock_objects.h

messages.author: Wez
messages.text: TearDown always calls Stop() on the daemon process, though, so surely calling this will crash the test?

messages.author: Wez
messages.text: Reminds me... I must land AutoThread, which tweaks AutoThreadTaskRunner to always call the shutdown task on the underlying task runner, so you can just pass QuitClosure() for cases like this...

messages.author: Wez
messages.text: If you're going to NULL |task_runner_| then it doesn't need to be a test member, does it?

On 2012/10/16 04:27:03, Wez wrote:
> TearDown always calls Stop() on the daemon process, though, so surely calling
> this will crash the test?

If it is called in wrong time - yes. But it is passed as a callback to stoppable. The object is deleted when is it completely stopped and it is fine to delete it.
